isis.stitle: DIAMONDLIFE™ (BOSCH PIN SLIDE) DISC BRAKES For Vehicles Built Before June 3, 2002 - install - ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD

svcprocinfo.para: During service procedure, keep grease and other foreign material from caliper assembly, disc brake pads, brake rotor and external surfaces of wheel hub. Handle parts carefully to avoid damage to caliper, rotor, disc brake pads and brake lines.
In the event the original disc brake pads are to be used again, use the markings made during removal, so that they are reinstalled in same location.
The following steps refer to only one wheel. The same procedure will need to be performed at each wheel.

note.para:
Several changes have been incorporated within the anchor plate assembly and caliper mounting bolts on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. It is important to recognize that these changes are not found on disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, unless a complete rebuild of the anchor plate assembly was performed on the vehicle. The components that have changed are the leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
and (Figure 68)
and caliper mounting bolts (Figure 71) .

svcsubproc.title: Install

figure.caption: Figure 81. Install Splash Shield and ABS Sensor Bracket on Anchor Plate

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 81
for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Install splash shield (Item 4) onto anchor plate (Item 2) as follows:

step2.para: When installing the splash shield (Item 4) on the anchor plate (Item 2) for 66 mm front and rear and 73 mm rear brakes, the splash shield is mounted on the inboard side of the anchor plate and the three 12-point head bolts (Item 5) are installed from the inboard side. Tighten to 13 to 16 ft-lbs. (17 to 21 N•m).

On the 73 mm front brakes, the splash shield (Item 4) is mounted on the outboard side of the anchor plate (Item 2) and the three 12-point head bolts (Item 5) are installed from the outboard side. Tighten to 13 to 16 ft-lbs. (17 to 21 N•m).

important.para: When installing the ABS sensor bracket (Item 1), the bracket is always installed on the same side of anchor plate as the splash shield, on the machined surface, with the long portion of the bracket on the same side as the mounting bolt heads.

step1.para: If so equipped, install ABS sensor bracket (Item 1) on anchor plate (Item 2) by installing two 12-point head bolts (Item 3), driver side front and rear shown. Tighten to 13 to 16 ft-lbs. (17 to 21 N•m).

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 82 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: On front axles with both 66 mm and 73 mm disc brakes, install anchor plate and splash shield (Items 1 and 2) on outboard side of steering knuckle flange (Item 4); align holes of anchor plate with holes in steering knuckle flange.

When reinstalling anchor plate, use new mounting hardware; this will ensure proper torque requirements. Install hex bolts (Item 5) from outboard side through anchor plate (Item 1) and steering knuckle flange (Item 4) and install hex lock nuts (Item 3) from inboard side of steering knuckle flange. Refer to TORQUE CHART
section for proper tightening specifications.

note.para: Install lock nut so that it seats firmly in chamfer against surface of the steering knuckle.

figure.caption: Figure 82. Install Anchor Plate and Splash Shield Assembly on Front Axle

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 83 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: On rear axles with both 66 mm and 73 mm disc brakes, install anchor plate and splash shield (Items 1 and 2) on outboard side of axle flange (Item 6); align holes of anchor plate with holes in axle flange.

When reinstalling anchor plate, use new mounting hardware; this will ensure proper torque requirements. Install hex bolts (Item 5) from inboard side through axle flange (Item 6) and anchor plate (Item 1) and install hex lock nuts with flat washers (Items 3 and 4) from outboard side of anchor plate. Tighten to 115 to 125 ft-lbs. (156 to 170 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 83. Install Anchor Plate and Splash Shield Assembly on Rear Axle

step1.para:
Install rotor and wheel hub assembly (Items 1 and 2, Figure 84). Refer to ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY, Install
.

figure.caption: Figure 84. Install Rotor and Wheel Hub Assembly

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 85 for Items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para:
Install caliper assembly (Item 1). Refer to CALIPER, Install
.

caution.para:
Be sure that the correct caliper mounting bolt, torque sequence and torque value is used during caliper installation. Vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002 used caliper hex mounting bolts M12-1.75 x 30 mm long, coarse thread, yellow/gold color (Figure 71)
used with leading and trailing guide pins that were the same. Vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002 use a caliper hex flanged mounting bolt M12-1.25 x 40 mm long, fine thread, dark-gray/black color (Figure 71)
used with new leading guide pin and trailing guide pin, new trailing guide pin has a rubber bushing. When performing service to vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, it is recommended to replace old guide pins (Figure 67)
that are the same with the new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
with the new hex flanged bolts.

step1.para: Install anchor plate tie bar (Item 2), if so equipped (73 mm brake assembly only), by installing 12-point head bolts (Item 3). Tighten to 40 to 50 ft-lbs. (54 to 68 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 85. Install Caliper Assembly and Anchor Plate Tie Bar

step1.para:
Install wheel (tire and rim) on vehicle and remove floor stands. Refer to GROUP 17 - WHEELS in the Master Service Manual for proper wheel installation. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications based on mounting hardware size and thread type.

note.para: When installing the wheel on disc brake axles, make sure the tire valve stem clears the brake caliper. The use of a valve stem retainer or a tire manufacturer's stem forming tool are the only acceptable methods of obtaining clearance when necessary.

step1.para: Check the master cylinder reservoir and fill if necessary. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the Master Service Manual for proper brake fluid.
After any brake service, be sure to test brakes prior to returning vehicle to service. A firm pedal should be felt during brake application.

If necessary, bleed brakes. Refer to BLEEDING INSTRUCTIONS
as follows.
